title: 'As it ceases to inspire, the US is losing part of itself'
subhed: Donald Trump's second term has turned the United States into a threat to which the rest of the world has no choice but to adapt. Yet, over the past eight decades, habits and practices have taken root that will be used to counter this new imperialism, writes Le Monde columnist Gilles Paris.

title: Trump cancels tariff threat over Greenland, says NATO agreed to 'framework' of future Arctic deal
byline: Le Monde with AP and AFP

title: US House panel begins push to hold Clintons in contempt over Epstein probe
European Parliament throws EU-Mercosur agreement into uncertainty
subhed: Members of the European Parliament have chosen to refer the free trade agreement to the Court of Justice of the European Union, effectively freezing the ratification process. The European Commission may, however, decide on provisional application.

title: French gender equality council warns of threat posed by masculinist networks
subhed: The High Council for Equality between Women and Men, which advises public authorities on gender equality, published a report on Wednesday that distinguishes between 'paternalistic' and 'hostile' sexism.

title: Paris men's fashion week: From the runway to live performance
subhed: Etudes Studio, Jeanne Friot, and Lemair: three labels choose cultural venues to bring a theatrical dimension to their collections.

title: Maya Kandel, historian: 'The more Trump uses force, the more confident he becomes'
subhed: Elected on an isolationist promise, the American president has multiplied foreign interventions. This policy risks weakening his MAGA base, the researcher says in an interview with Le Monde.

title: Israeli strike kills three Gaza journalists including AFP freelancer
Marine Le Pen insists party acted in 'good faith' at appeal trial
'French military involvement in Greenland is not for show'
'The Wizard of the Kremlin': An epic tale of power through the eyes of a man in the shadows
Ubisoft unveils details of big restructuring bet
Trump's desire to avoid military force over Greenland a 'positive' sign, Denmark says
Lactalis recalls baby formula in several countries over toxin
'Board of Peace': Four questions to understand Trump's UN rival
Davos takes stock of a transatlantic alliance trampled by Trump
byline: By Claire Gatinois and Philippe Ricard (Davos (Switzerland), special correspondent)

title: Syria's government gives Kurds more time to reach an agreement
Why Morocco's king accepted to join Trump's 'Board of Peace'
Claude Le Roy: 'The Senegalese players were overwhelmed by emotion and completely lost control'
In the Ukrainian Carpathians, peace feels both near and far
subhed: In Uzhhorod, a border city near Slovakia, exhausted and disillusioned residents have long stopped believing in victory and expect little from ongoing diplomatic talks. They only hope that the war will end, even 'if it means sacrificing a piece of the country to be saved.'
byline: By Florence Aubenas (Uzhhorod, Ukraine, special correspondent)

title: Marine Duc, geographer: 'In Greenland, the memory of colonial violence remains strong'
subhed: Donald Trump's ambitions for the Arctic island have affected Danish policies toward the Inuit population and influenced the expression of Greenlandic nationalism, the academic explained in an interview with Le Monde.

title: Bastien François, political scientist: 'There are good and bad ways to use Article 49.3' of the French Constitution
subhed: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu's decision to ram the budget through Parliament without a vote, using Article 49.3 of the Constitution, is not undemocratic, explains political science professor Bastien François.

title: A 'Board of Peace,' to do what?
The necessary showdown with Donald Trump
Terror, the Iranian regime's last resort
